DIA_INFX.name: Influenza A
DIA_INFX.description: Influenza, commonly known as 'the flu', is a common infectious disease caused by the influenza virus family.

DIA_HEPAX.name: Hepatitis A
DIA_HEPAX.description: Hepatitis refers to a viral infection of the liver. Hepatitis A virus spreads through feces and usually occurs in areas with poor sanitation or hygiene.

DIA_HEPBX.name: Hepatitis B
DIA_HEPBX.description: Hepatitis refers to a viral infection of the liver. Hepatitis B virus spreads via blood, sexual contact or from mother to child.

DIA_CLCX.name: Cholera
DIA_CLCX.description: Cholera is a bacterial disease that usually spread through contaminated water. Modern sewage and water treatment eliminated cholera in industrialized countries.

DIA_TYFX.name: Typhoid fever
DIA_TYFX.description: Typhoid fever is a bacterial disease that spreads through contaminated water and food. It is rare in industrialized countries.

DIA_TBCX.name: Tuberculosis
DIA_TBCX.description: Tuberculosis of the lungs is a serious disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium tuberculosis affecting mainly lungs, but it can spread to other organs such as the brain.

DIA_TULX.name: Tularaemia
DIA_TULX.description: Tularaemia is an infectious disease that mainly affects the skin, eyes, lymph nodes or lungs. It is caused by the Francisella tularensis bacteria. Tulareamia is highly contagious, potentially fatal, but can be treated effectively.

DIA_PNAX.name: Pulmonary anthrax
DIA_PNAX.description: Anthrax is serious infection caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis. It is spread through the bacteria's spores. Contact is made typically by inhaling or eating the spores or through skin lesions.

DIA_RBFX.name: Rat-bite fever
DIA_RBFX.description: Rat-bite fever is an acute febrile disease caused by bacteria transmitted by rodents, particularly by their urine or mucous secretions.

DIA_CSDX.name: Cat-scratch disease
DIA_CSDX.description: Cat-scratch disease is a common infectious disease caused by Bartonella henselae. It is transmitted by cats, through the cat's scratch or bite. Presence of the bacteria in humans is hard to detect by traditional bacterial cultivation because growth takes up to 6 weeks.

DIA_PTSX.name: Pertussis
DIA_PTSX.description: Pertussis also known as Whooping Cough is a contagious respiratory disease. It is caused by the bacteria Bordetella pertussis. Before the development of a vaccine, pertussis was considered a childhood disease. Now it affects people whose immunedefense is weakened.

DIA_LEGX.name: Legionnaires disease
DIA_LEGX.description: Legionnaires disease is caused by the bacterium Legionella pneumophila. The disease develops into a severe form of pneumonia, transmitting through person to person. Untreated Legionnaires diseases are usually fatal.

DIA_TPFX.name: Typhus fever
DIA_TPFX.description: Important not to be confused with Typhoid fever. Typhus is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia Typhi, transmitted through various types of fleas. Typhus was first described in 1528. It has a sudden onset of various symptoms comparable to the common flu.

DIA_ATSX.name: American trypanosomias
DIA_ATSX.description: American trypanosomias also known as Chagas disease is serious infectious disease caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. If left untreated, it can lead to serious heart and digestive complications.

DIA_TXMX.name: Toxoplasmosis
DIA_TXMX.description: Toxoplasmosis is caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii. Symptoms are similar to the common flu. The parasite is spread through undercooked food and exposure to cat's feces.

DIA_BABX.name: Babesiosis
DIA_BABX.description: Babesiosis is parasitic disease caused by the parasite Babesia. It is comparable to malaria. It spreads through ticks and often presents with Lyme disease.

DIA_LYDX.name: Lyme disease
DIA_LYDX.description: Lyme disease is caused by the bite of a deer tick or back-legged tick. It can transfer a bacteria, Borrelia burgdorferi, which directly causes disease.

DIA_MUMX.name: Mumps
DIA_MUMX.description: Mumps also known as Parotitis, is an inflammatory, infectious disease affecting the parotid glands (on one or on both sides of the head). The inflammation is caused by bacterial or viral agents. It is best prevented by vaccination.

DIA_TBEX.name: Tick-borne encephalitis
DIA_TBEX.description: Tick-borne encephalitis is a viral tick-borne infectious disease involving brain and central nervous system.

DIA_RABX.name: Rabies
DIA_RABX.description: Rabies is a deadly virus spread by saliva of infected animals. Transmission is often through animal bites.

DIA_001.name: Anaplasmosis
DIA_001.description: Anaplasmosis is caused by bacteria Anaplasmosis phagocytophilum that is spread by ticks.

DIA_002.name: Ehrlichiosis
DIA_002.description: Ehrlichiosis is a flu-like disease that is closely related to Anaplasmosis. It is also spread by ticks.

DIA_003.name: Boutonneuse fever
DIA_003.description: Boutonneuse fever is a fever caused by rickettsial infection caused by Rickettsia conorii and it is transmitted by the dog tick. The disease occurrs mainly in the Mediterranean basin, Middle East, Indian subcontinent and Africa.

DIA_004.name: Rocky Mountain spotted fever
DIA_004.description: Bacterial disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, spread by various species of ticks (american dog tick, rocky mountain wood tick, brown dog tick).

DIA_005.name: Colorado tick fever
DIA_005.description: Viral infection spread by Rocky Mountain wood tick, symptoms are very similar to Rocky Mountain spotted fever.

DIA_006.name: Pacific Coast tick fever
DIA_006.description: Bacterial disease caused by Rickettsia philipii, spread by Pacific coast tick.

DIA_007.name: African tick bite fever
DIA_007.description: African tick bite fever - ATBF is a bacterial infection caused by Rickettsia africae, spread by ticks. The disease occurs in Sub-Saharan Africa, Carribean and Oceania.

DIA_008.name: Queensland tick typhus
DIA_008.description: The etiologic agent of Queensland tick typhus is bacteria Rickettsia australis. The disease occurs only in Eastern Australia, including Tasmania.

DIA_009.name: Flinders Island spotted fever
DIA_009.description: Flinders Island spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia honei and the disease occurs mainly in southeast and south Asia and also in Australia.

DIA_010.name: Japanese spotted fever
DIA_010.description: Japanese spotted fever occurs mainly in warm areas along the Pacific side of southwest and central Japan. The disease is caused by Rickettsia japonica, transmitted via a tick bite.

DIA_011.name: TIBOLA
DIA_011.description: Tick-borne lymphadenopathy is a tick-borne rickettsiosis relatively common in central Europe and casued by Rickettsia slovaca.

DIA_012.name: Rickettsialpox
DIA_012.description: Rickettsialpox is a mite-borne infectious disease caused by Rickettsia akari, that is spread by mites usually living on house mice.

DIA_013.name: Brucellosis
DIA_013.description: Brucellosis is disease caused by Brucella species bacteria and it is spread by ingestion of unpasterized milk or undercooked meat.

DIA_014.name: Chikungunya
DIA_014.description: Chikungunya virus infection is spread by the bite of an infected mosquito. There is no vaccine.

DIA_015.name: Q - fever
DIA_015.description: Q fever is a disease caused by Coxiella burnetti and it is spread by various animals like cattle, sheep, goats, cats and dogs. The bacterium is an intracellular parasite, capable of growth and reproduction inside the hosts cells.

DIA_016.name: Dengue fever
DIA_016.description: Dengue fever is a tropical disease transmitted by infected mosquito's bite.

DIA_017.name: Zika fever
DIA_017.description: Zika fever is tropical disease caused by Zika virus and it is spread by the Aedes mosquitos.

DIA_018.name: Ebola
DIA_018.description: Ebola virus disease is a deadly viral hemorrhagic fever. It is caused by ebolaviruses, spread by direct contact with infected body fluids.

DIA_019.name: Malaria
DIA_019.description: Malaria is a tropical infectious disease caused by parasites from the plasmodium group. It is spread via infected mosquito bites.

DIA_020.name: Yellow fever
DIA_020.description: Yellow fever is a tropical viral disease that is spread by the bite of an infected female mosquito. It is caused by yellow fever virus, enveloped RNA virus of the family Flaviridae.

DIA_021.name: West Nile fever
DIA_021.description: West Nile fever is an infection caused by the West Nile virus, the disease is spread by infected mosquitos. Most people do not develop any symptoms. The virus was discovered in Uganda in 1937.

DIA_022.name: Lassa fever
DIA_022.description: Also known as Lassa hemorrhagic fever is caused by the Lassa virus that is spread specifically by African rats.

DIA_023.name: Marburg
DIA_023.description: Marburg virus disease is a severe disease that affects humans and non-human primates, caused by either of two marburgviruses - Marburg virus and Ravn virus.

DIA_024.name: Leptospirosis
DIA_024.description: Leptospirosis is a blood infection caused by bacteria Leptospira and it is typically spread by rodents.

DIA_025.name: C. difficile infection
DIA_025.description: Clostridium difficile infection is caused by toxin-producing bacteria. It can be fatal.

DIA_026.name: Valley Fever
DIA_026.description: Valley fever, also called Coccidioidomycosis, is an infection caused by fungus Coccidioides that lives in the soil of the southwestern US, Mexico and central and South America.

DIA_027.name: COVID-19
DIA_027.description: COVID-19 is the disease caused by the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 and causes a respiratory infection. First identified in Wu-han, China in December 2019, the disease spread world-wide, causing the biggest pandemic since the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic.

DIA_028.name: MERS
DIA_028.description: MERS - Middle East respiratory syndrome, also known as Camel flu, is a highly contagious viral respiratory infection caused by MERS-coronavirus.

DIA_029.name: SARS
DIA_029.description: SARS - Severe acute respiratory syndrome is a viral respiratory disease caused by the SARS coronavirus. The first outbreak occurred in southern China between November 2002 and July 2003.

DIA_030.name: Respiratory crypto
DIA_030.description: Cryptosporidiosis is a parasitic disease caused by protozoan parasites named Cryptosporidium. It affects the respiratory system and also the digestive tract.

DIA_031.name: Intestinal crypto
DIA_031.description: Cryptosporidiosis is a parasitic disease caused by protozoan parasites named Cryptosporidium. It affects the digestive apparatus and also the respiratory system.

DIA_032.name: HPS
DIA_032.description: HPS - Hantavirus Pulmonary syndrome is a serious viral respiratory disease caused by hantaviruses spread by rodents.

DIA_033.name: Norovirus
DIA_033.description: Norovirus, also called winter vomiting bug is a virus that causes diarrhea and vomiting. People that are infected can shed billions of norovirus particles.

DIA_034.name: Rotavirus A
DIA_034.description: Rotavirus A causes watery diarrhea. The best prevention is vaccination.

DIA_035.name: Melioidosis
DIA_035.description: Melioidosis, also called Whitmore's disease is an infectious disease caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei and it is transmitted by both animals and contaminated soil or water.

DIA_036.name: Respiratory Syncytial Virus
DIA_036.description: HRSV - also known as Human orthopneumovirus is a syncytial virus causing respiratory infections.

DIA_037.name: Lymphocytic choriomeningitis
DIA_037.description: Lymphocytic choriomeningitis is a rodent-borne viral infectious disease caused by lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, spread commonly by house mice.

DIA_038.name: Bubonic plague
DIA_038.description: Bubonic plague is one of the three types of plague caused by bacterium Yersinia pestis. Bubonic plague is spread by infected fleas living on small animals. It is specific in its infection of lymph nodes, that become extremely swollen.

DIA_039.name: Septicemic plague
DIA_039.description: Septicemic plague is one of the three types of plague caused by bacterium Yersinia pestis. Septicemic plague is spread by infected fleas living on small animals. It is the rarest of all three forms, typically infecting the blood.

DIA_040.name: Pneumonic plague
DIA_040.description: Pneumonic plague is one of the three types of plague caused by bacterium Yersinia pestis. It is spread by infected fleas living on small animals. The pneumonic form causes a pulmonary infection.

DIA_041.name: Nipah virus infection
DIA_041.description: Nipah virus infection is a serious and potentially fatal disease, caused by an RNA virus in the genus Henipavirus. It spreads between people and can also transmit from animals to humans.

DIA_042.name: Rift Valley fever
DIA_042.description: Rift Valley fever is a viral disease, caused by RVF virus that is transmitted via animal body fluids.

DIA_043.name: Relapsing fever
DIA_043.description: Relapsing fever is an infectious vectro-borne disease, caused by a group of bacteria in the genus Borelia and it is transmitted via bites of lice or soft-bodied ticks.

DIA_044.name: Acute hepatitis E
DIA_044.description: Hepatitis E is an inflammation of the liver caused by Hepatitis E virus. Transmission is similar to Hepatitis A, but the viruses are unrelated. First recorded in 1955, but virus was isolated for the first time in 1983.

DIA_045.name: H5N1 Bird flu
DIA_045.description: Influenza A virus - subtype H5N1 is a highly pathogenic avian influenza. The only way of transmission to humans is from birds. The first global spread was recorded in 2004.
